description: From Middle English serpentine, from Old French serpentin, from Latin serpentīnus, from serpēns (“serpent”).

adjectives.description: serpentine (comparative more serpentine, superlative most serpentine)

entries.meaning: Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of snakes.
Of, or having attributes associated with, the serpent referred to in the book of Genesis in the Bible, such as craftiness or deceitfulness.
examples: The wily criminal was known for his serpentine behavior.

entries.meaning: Having the form or shape of a snake.
examples: There are serpentine species of lizards which do not have legs.
The serpentine path through the mountains was narrow and dangerous.

entries.meaning: Any of several plants believed to cure snakebites.
(historical) An early form of cannon, used in the 16th century.
(mathematics) Any of several related cubic curves; anguinea
(equestrianism) in dressage, a winding walk across on the arena

verbs.description: serpentine (third-person singular simple present serpentines, present participle serpentining, simple past and past participle serpentined)

entries.meaning: (archaic) To serpentize; to turn or bend; to meander.
examples: There were two little lakes, or rather large pools which stood in the bottom, whence issued a rivulet which serpentined in view for two or three miles, offering a pleasing relief to the eye.

description: From Middle English serpentine, from Old French serpentine, from resemblance to a serpent's skin.

entries.meaning: (mineralogy) Any of several green/brown minerals consisting of magnesium and iron silicates that have similar layered crystal structure.
(geology) An outcrop or region with soil and rock dominated by these minerals.
